term.title: Deoxyribonucleic Acid
term.definition: Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) is a molecule composed of two polynucleotide chains that coil around each other to form a double helix carrying genetic instructions for the development, functioning, growth, and reproduction of all known organisms and many viruses.
term.context: DNA is used in genetic research and forensic science.
term.note: DNA is essential for inheritance, coding for proteins, and the genetic instruction guide for life and its processes.

term.title: HyperText Markup Language
term.definition: HyperText Markup Language (HTML) is the standard markup language for documents designed to be displayed in a web browser. It can be assisted by technologies such as Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) and scripting languages such as JavaScript.
term.context: HTML is used to create web pages and web applications.
term.note: HTML elements are the building blocks of HTML pages.

term.title: International Business Machines
term.definition: International Business Machines Corporation (IBM) is an American multinational technology and consulting company headquartered in Armonk, New York, with operations in over 170 countries. The company began in 1911 as the Computing-Tabulating-Recording Company (CTR) and was renamed "International Business Machines" in 1924.
term.context: IBM is known for its computer hardware and software, as well as its consulting services.
term.note: IBM has a long history of innovation in the technology industry.

term.title: Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation
term.definition: Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation (LASER) is a device that emits light through a process of optical amplification based on the stimulated emission of electromagnetic radiation. The term "laser" originated as an acronym for "light amplification by stimulated emission of radiation".
term.context: Lasers are used in various applications, including medicine, industry, and communication.
term.note: Lasers can produce a very narrow beam of light that can be focused on a small area.
term.incorrectTerm: Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation

term.title: Global Positioning System
term.definition: The Global Positioning System (GPS) is a satellite-based radionavigation system owned by the United States government and operated by the United States Space Force. It provides geolocation and time information to a GPS receiver anywhere on or near the Earth where there is an unobstructed line of sight to four or more GPS satellites.
term.context: GPS is used in navigation, mapping, and timing applications.
term.note: GPS is essential for modern navigation and location-based services.

term.title: Personal Computer
term.definition: A personal computer (PC) is a multi-purpose computer whose size, capabilities, and price make it feasible for individual use. PCs are intended to be operated directly by an end user, rather than by a computer expert or technician.
term.context: PCs are used in homes, schools, and businesses for various tasks.
term.note: PCs have revolutionized the way people work, learn, and communicate.

term.title: Central Processing Unit
term.definition: The central processing unit (CPU) is the electronic circuitry within a computer that executes instructions that make up a computer program. The CPU performs basic arithmetic, logic, controlling, and input/output (I/O) operations specified by the instructions in the program.
term.context: CPUs are the primary component of computers responsible for interpreting and executing most of the commands from the computer's other hardware and software.
term.note: CPUs are often referred to as the "brains" of the computer.

term.title: Random Access Memory
term.definition: Random Access Memory (RAM) is a form of computer memory that can be read and changed in any order, typically used to store working data and machine code. A random-access memory device allows data items to be read or written in almost the same amount of time irrespective of the physical location of data inside the memory.
term.context: RAM is used in computers and other devices to store data that is being used actively.
term.note: RAM is volatile memory, meaning it loses its data when the power is turned off.

term.title: Operating System
term.definition: An operating system (OS) is system software that manages computer hardware, software resources, and provides common services for computer programs.
term.context: Operating systems like Windows, macOS, and Linux are used in computers.
term.note: The OS provides a user interface and manages file systems.

term.title: Artificial Intelligence
term.definition: Artificial Intelligence (AI) refers to the simulation of human intelligence in machines programmed to think like humans and mimic their actions.
term.context: AI is used in various fields including robotics, natural language processing, and expert systems.
term.note: AI encompasses machine learning and deep learning techniques.

term.title: Machine Learning
term.definition: Machine Learning (ML) is a subset of AI that involves the development of algorithms that allow computers to learn from and make decisions based on data.
term.context: ML is applied in data analytics and predictive modeling.
term.note: ML algorithms improve automatically through experience.

term.title: Virtual Reality
term.definition: Virtual Reality (VR) is a simulated experience that can be similar to or completely different from the real world.
term.context: VR is used in gaming, training, and simulation environments.
term.note: VR creates immersive, interactive environments.

term.title: Augmented Reality
term.definition: Augmented Reality (AR) overlays digital information on the real world, enhancing one's perception of reality.
term.context: AR is used in mobile applications, advertising, and education.
term.note: AR blends digital content with the physical environment.

term.title: Blockchain Technology
term.definition: Blockchain is a decentralized ledger of all transactions across a peer-to-peer network.
term.context: Blockchain is used in cryptocurrencies and smart contracts.
term.note: Blockchain ensures transparency and security in digital transactions.

term.title: Cloud Computing
term.definition: Cloud Computing is the on-demand delivery of IT resources over the internet with pay-as-you-go pricing.
term.context: Cloud computing is used for data storage, servers, and software.
term.note: Cloud services allow scalability and remote access to computing resources.

term.title: Encryption
term.definition: Encryption is the process of converting information into a code to prevent unauthorized access.
term.context: Encryption is crucial for secure communication and data protection.
term.note: Encryption algorithms protect sensitive data from breaches.

term.title: Database Management System
term.definition: A Database Management System (DBMS) is software for creating and managing databases.
term.context: DBMS are used to store, retrieve, and manage data in various applications.
term.note: DBMS simplifies data management and ensures data integrity.

term.title: Integrated Circuit
term.definition: An Integrated Circuit (IC) is a set of electronic circuits on one small chip of semiconductor material.
term.context: ICs are used in virtually all electronic equipment.
term.note: ICs have revolutionized electronics by miniaturizing circuits.

term.title: Microprocessor
term.definition: A Microprocessor is a computer processor on a microchip, integrating the functions of a computer's central processing unit.
term.context: Microprocessors are used in computers and many other digital devices.
term.note: Microprocessors are the heart of modern computing devices.

term.title: Semiconductor
term.definition: A Semiconductor is a material that has electrical conductivity between that of a conductor and an insulator.
term.context: Semiconductors are fundamental components in electronic devices.
term.note: They are used in integrated circuits and transistors.

term.title: Transistor
term.definition: A transistor is a semiconductor device used to amplify or switch electronic signals and electrical power.
term.context: Transistors are the building blocks of modern electronic devices.
term.note: They replaced vacuum tubes in most electronic applications.

term.title: Quantum Computing
term.definition: Quantum Computing is a type of computation that harnesses quantum mechanics to perform operations on data.
term.context: Quantum computing is used in research to solve complex problems beyond classical computers.
term.note: It utilizes qubits instead of traditional bits.

term.title: Software Development
term.definition: Software Development is the process of conceiving, specifying, designing, programming, and testing applications and systems.
term.context: It is used to create various software solutions across industries.
term.note: Agile methodologies are popular in modern software development.

term.title: Networking
term.definition: Networking involves the exchange of data between nodes connected by a network.
term.context: It is crucial for communication in computer systems and the internet.
term.note: Technologies include LAN, WAN, and VPN.

term.title: Mobile Application
term.definition: A Mobile Application is a software application developed specifically for use on smartphones and other mobile devices.
term.context: Mobile apps are used for a wide range of tasks on the go.
term.note: They are designed for user convenience and portability.

term.title: User Interface
term.definition: The User Interface (UI) is the space where interactions between humans and machines occur.
term.context: A well-designed UI is crucial for effective human-computer interaction.
term.note: Good UI design enhances overall user experience.

term.title: User Experience
term.definition: User Experience (UX) refers to a person's emotions and attitudes about using a particular product, system or service.
term.context: UX is critical in product design and service delivery.
term.note: Focusing on UX can significantly improve customer satisfaction.

term.title: Application Programming Interface
term.definition: An Application Programming Interface (API) is a set of protocols and tools for building software applications.
term.context: APIs allow different software systems to communicate and integrate.
term.note: They enable developers to use predefined functions to build applications.

term.title: Big Data
term.definition: Big Data refers to extremely large datasets that may be analyzed computationally to reveal patterns, trends, and associations.
term.context: It is used in analytics and decision-making processes.
term.note: Handling Big Data requires advanced processing tools and techniques.

term.title: Internet of Things
term.definition: The Internet of Things (IoT) refers to the network of physical objects embedded with sensors, software, and other technologies that connect and exchange data with other devices and systems over the internet.
term.context: IoT is used in smart homes, healthcare, and industrial applications.
term.note: It enables remote monitoring and automation in various sectors.
